content.text: Define acceleration
On Fig. 1.1, draw a line to show the path of the parcel as it falls from the aircraft to the ground
Calculate the time taken from the instant of release to the instant the parcel reaches the ground
Calculate the vertical component of the velocity of the parcel immediately before it reaches the ground
vertical component of velocity = .........m s⁻¹
Determine the speed at which the parcel reaches the ground
speed = .........m s⁻¹
A small aircraft is flying horizontally at a speed of \(42 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at a height of \(63 \text{m}\) above horizontal ground, as shown in Fig. 1.1
The aircraft drops a small parcel. The parcel is released from the aircraft at the instant shown in Fig. 1.1. Air resistance is negligible
State the principle of conservation of momentum
Show that the speed \(\nu\) of ball Y after the collision is \(8.0 \text{m s}^{- 1}\)
Calculate the change in the total kinetic energy \(\Delta E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of the balls due to the collision
\(\Delta E_{\mathrm{K}} =\) .........J

A ball X has mass \(240\mathrm{g}\) and moves in a straight line on a horizontal frictionless surface with an initial speed of \(16\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) . The ball collides with a stationary ball Y that has mass \(480\mathrm{g}\) . After the collision, ball X is stationary, as shown in Fig. 2.1
mass \(240\mathrm{g}\)
ball Y,
mass \(480\mathrm{g}\)
ball X,
mass \(240\mathrm{g}\)
BEFORE
AFTER
Determine the magnitude and direction of the force exerted on ball X by ball Y during the collision
magnitude = .........N
direction
Compare the magnitude and direction of the force exerted on ball Y by ball X during the collision with the answers in (c)(i). No further calculations are required
The collision in (b) lasts for a time of 2.0 ms. Assume that the contact force between the balls is constant during this time
State the principle of moments
Use the principle of moments to show that the upthrust \(U\) exerted by the water on the cylinder is \(1.4 \text{N}\)
The density of the water is \(1.0 \times 10^{3} \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\)
Calculate the area \(A\) of the circular cross-section of the cylinder
A rigid uniform beam rests on a pivot at its centre, as shown in Fig. 3.1
A load of weight \(2.6 \text{N}\) is suspended from the beam at distance \(x\) from the pivot

A wooden cylinder of weight \(4.0 \text{N}\) is suspended from the beam at a distance of \(0.40 \text{m}\) from the pivot on the opposite side of the pivot to the load. The cylinder rests in a container of water. The lower part of the cylinder is immersed in the water to depth \(h\)
Initially, \(h\) is equal to \(0.10 \text{m}\) and \(x\) is equal to \(0.40 \text{m}\). The system is in equilibrium
More water is gradually added to the container in **(b)**, so that depth \(h\) in Fig. 3.1 gradually increases. The length \(x\) is continuously adjusted so that the system remains in equilibrium
On Fig. 3.2, sketch the variation of \(x\) with \(h\). Use the space below for any working
stress
strain
Define:
Determine the cross-sectional area of wire X
cross-sectional area = .........m²
Wire Y has a greater diameter than wire X
Explain, without calculation, whether the Young modulus of the metal from which wire Y is made is less than, the same as or greater than \(1.9 \times 10^9 \text{Pa}\)

Two wires X and Y, with equal unstretched lengths of \(0.84 \text{m}\), are suspended from fixed points that are at the same horizontal level. The lower ends of the wires are attached to a beam of negligible mass. The beam is horizontal and in equilibrium, as shown in Fig. 4.1
Wire X is made from a metal that has a Young modulus of \(1.9 \times 10^9 \text{Pa}\)
Wire Y is made from a different metal
A load of weight \(18 \text{N}\) is suspended from the beam at a point that is equidistant from the two wires. This load causes both wires to extend by \(0.47 \text{mm}\)
On Fig. 5.1, draw a cross \((\times)\) at one position that is a node and another cross at one position that is an antinode. Label the node N and the antinode A.
Show that the wavelength of the wave produced is \(0.32 \text{m}\). Explain your reasoning
Calculate the frequency of the wave
frequency = .........Hz
A stationary wave is formed on a string XY that has a length of \(0.48 \text{m}\). Fig. 5.1 shows the string at one instant in time
The speed of the wave on the string is \(1400 \text{m s}^{-1}\)
The speed of sound in air is \(320 \text{m s}^{-1}\)
Calculate the maximum frequency of the sound detected by the observer
maximum frequency = .........Hz
At time \(t = 0\), the observer detects the sound emitted by the source when it was in the position shown in Fig. 5.2
On Fig. 5.3, sketch the variation with \(t\) of the frequency \(f\) of the sound detected by the observer for one complete rotation of the platform. Calculations are not required
A source of sound waves of frequency \(780\mathrm{Hz}\) is on a rotating platform. The speed of the source is \(39\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\)
The sound is detected by an observer that is a large distance from the rotating platform, as shown in Fig. 5.2
Define resistance
Determine the resistivity of the metal from which the wire is made
resistivity = .........\(\Omega\) m
Calculate the charge that passes through the wire in a time of 5.0 minutes
charge = .........C
The free electrons (charge carriers) in the wire have an average drift speed of \(0.16 \text{mm} \text{s}^{-1}\)
Determine the number density of charge carriers in the metal
number density = .........m⁻³
A cylindrical metal wire of length \(2.4 \text{m}\) and cross-sectional area \(8.0 \times 10^{-6} \text{m}^2\) has a resistance of \(0.33 \Omega\). There is a current in the wire of \(4.7 \text{A}\)
Use circuit symbols to complete Fig. 6.1 to show the circuit diagram of this arrangement
Explain, without calculation, how the power dissipated in the wire changes as the temperature of the thermistor is increased
The wire in (b) may be considered to be a fixed resistor. It is connected in series with a thermistor to a battery that has negligible internal resistance
Complete Table 7.1 to show the charges, in terms of the elementary charge \(e\), on each of the flavours of quark and antiquark shown
State the name of the class (group) of fundamental particles to which baryons and mesons belong
Compare baryons and mesons in terms of their constituent particles
Describe \(\beta^{+}\) decay in terms of the fundamental particles involved
